Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Perioperative Oxygen Therapy

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the effectiveness of perioperative oxygen strategies.

Participants.evidence: Participants undergoing surgery were included based on eligibility criteria, and the study was conducted in a hospital setting.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either a high fraction of inspired oxygen or a low fraction.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the effectiveness of perioperative oxygen strategies.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of surgical site infection, measured within 30 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the high oxygen group and 100 to the low oxygen group, between April 2018 and March 2022.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the high oxygen group and 97 in the low oxygen group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The high oxygen group showed a slight reduction in surgical site infection (risk ratio 0.91, 95% CI 0.78 to 1.05).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included increased atelectasis in the high oxygen group (risk ratio 1.47, 95% CI 1.20 to 1.79) and a slight increase in postoperative pulmonary complications (risk ratio 1.06, 95% CI 0.77 to 1.46).

Funding.evidence: Funding: National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) Health Technology Assessment programme (NIHR award ref: NIHR132987).
